issues.description: Whether the district court erred in dismissing the securities fraud class action for failure to adequately allege false or misleading statements and scienter under Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5.
issues.key_reasoning: The appellate court found that the complaint plausibly alleged that Charles River knowingly or recklessly misled investors regarding its supply chain's exposure to federal investigation and indictment, and that the district court erred in dismissing the action for failure to state a claim.

issues.description: Whether the district court erred in finding that the complaint failed to adequately allege scienter (intent or recklessness) on the part of Charles River.
issues.key_reasoning: The court held that the complaint's allegations, taken as true, gave rise to a strong inference of scienter because Charles River made misleading statements about its supply chain while knowing of its exposure to the indicted suppliers.

issues.description: Whether the district court erred in not reaching the issue of loss causation and whether the appellate court should affirm on that alternative ground.
issues.key_reasoning: The appellate court declined to reach the loss causation issue, finding it complex and better addressed by the district court in the first instance.

issues.description: Whether Charles River's repeated statements about possibly using 'non-preferred vendors' were independently actionable as false or misleading.
issues.key_reasoning: The court agreed with the district court that the complaint did not sufficiently allege that the term 'non-preferred vendors' would be understood to mean vendors under law enforcement scrutiny, and thus these statements were not independently actionable.

key_precedents: Tellabs, Inc. v. Makor Issues & Rts., Ltd., 551 U.S. 308 (2007)
Karth v. Keryx Biopharmaceuticals, Inc., 6 F.4th 123 (1st Cir. 2021)
City of Mia. Fire Fighters' and Police Officers' Ret. Tr. v. CVS Health Corp., 46 F.4th 22 (1st Cir. 2022)
Mehta v. Ocular Therapeutix, Inc., 955 F.3d 194 (1st Cir. 2020)
Meyer v. Jinkosolar Holdings Co., 761 F.3d 245 (2d Cir. 2014)
summary_text:
Lead plaintiff State Teachers Retirement System of Ohio ("State Teachers") and other investors of defendant Charles River Laboratories International, Inc. ("Charles River") brought this securities-fraud class action alleging that Charles River and two of its officers misled investors as to the integrity of the overseas supply chain undergirding its supply of long-tailed macaques -- a central part of the company's business. Charles River moved to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a claim. The district court agreed that State Teachers had failed to allege false or misleading statements as well as scienter; thus, without reaching any further issues, the district court dismissed the action. State Teachers timely appealed.

For the following reasons, we agree with State Teachers that it plausibly alleged that Charles River knowingly or recklessly misled investors as to problems lurking in its supply chain. We therefore reverse the district court's dismissal of the complaint as to one set of misleading statements. And we remand for the district court to consider in the first instance whether State Teachers plausibly alleged that any of its losses were caused by Charles River's misdirection.
